text: Induction of CD8 T cells and NK Cell Infiltration into Tumor and Spleen of <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - Mice

To investigate whether the inhibition of tumor growth in <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice is related to tumor - specific immune responses , we analyzed the distribution patterns of CD8+ cytotoxic T cell and CD57+ Natural Killer cells in tumor and spleen tissues .

By staining the tumor sections from <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice , we found that there was a significant influx of CD8+ cells into the tumor , as well as an increase in the number of infiltrating NK cells ( Figure 5A ) .
CD8+ T cells and CD57+ NK cells were spread diffusely throughout the entire sections .

To further investigate the differences in the numbers of CD8+ T cells and CD57+ NK cells between <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + / + mice and <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice in immunity-related organ , we also analyzed the CD8 and CD57 reactive cell number in spleen tissues .

The number of CD8+ T cells and CD57+ NK cells were higher in the spleen of the <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice than in the spleen of the <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + / + mice ( Figure 5B ) .

These data suggest that by promoting the infiltration of CD8 T cells and NK cells , which are potent cytotoxic effectors for tumors , could play a role in an anti-tumor effect in <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice .

To analyze the cell phenotype change in <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice and <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + / + mice by inoculation of the melanoma cell , lymphocytes were isolated from the tumor and spleen tissues .

The B , CD3 T , <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T , CD 8 T and NK cell portion of <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice tumor tissue were 7.2 % , 48.2 % , 16.9 % , 32.1 % and 7.8 % , respectively , compared to 2.9 % , 11.1 % , 2.3 % , 0.6 % and 3.1 % of <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + / + mice ( Figure 5C ) .

The lymphocytes that infiltrated the tumor tissue of the <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice also had higher levels of <extra_id_0> CD19 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , CD3 , <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , CD8 and CD57 when compared to the <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + / + mice .

The B , CD3 T , <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T , CD 8 T and NK cell portion of the <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice spleen were 61.3 % , 33.4 % , 17.6 % , 9.2 % and 0.6 % , respectively compared to 38.3 % , 5.9 % , 4.0 % , 1.0 % and 3.9 % of the <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + / + mice ( Figure 5D ) .

These data suggest that by promoting the infiltration of CD8 T cells and NK cells , which are potent cytotoxic effectors for tumors , could play a role in the inhibition of tumor growth in <extra_id_0> CCR5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice .
